Award.AwardTitle: Probing Van der Waals Coupled One-Dimensional Physics in Double-Walled Carbon Nanotubes
Award.AbstractNarration:
NONTECHNICAL ABSTRACT

The award funds a project that investigates novel one-dimensional(1D) physics in double-walled carbon nanotubes, a model family of van der Waals-coupled 1D materials. One-dimensional carbon nanotubes have remarkable electrical, mechanical, and optical properties. This research project aims at advancing fundamental understanding of these 1D carbon materials, the knowledge of which could enable new types of electronic and photonic devices. The project provides an interdisciplinary learning environment, where graduate and undergraduate students can learn state-of-the-art laser spectroscopy and nanoscale fabrication, and collaborate with theorists and other experimentalists internationally. The project also takes advantage of the diverse student body and education activities in UC Berkeley to enhance broad participation in science and technology.

TECHNICAL ABSTRACT

This award funds a project that aims at fundamental understanding of van der Waals coupled one-dimensional physics in double-walled carbon nanotubes (DWNTs). DWNTs provides an ideal family of model systems to explore new 1D physics arising from van der Waals interactions: there are hundreds of different DWNT species, and each DWNT specie is uniquely characterized by the chiral indices of the constituent outer and inner single-walled carbon nanotubes. The perfect structure and rich variety of DWNTs is quite unique, and it enables quantitative and systematic studies of emerging 1D physics in different van der Waals-coupled structures. In this project, the principle investigator plans to investigate novel 1D phenomena in different DWNTs using a combination of single-tube spectroscopy and electron diffraction on individual DWNTs. In particular, the research activities cover three exciting directions: (1) Electronic structure renormalization in incommensurate DWNTs (2) Coupling between excitons and Luttinger liquid in metal/semiconductor DWNTs (i.e. DWNTs composed of a metallic outer wall and a semiconducting inner wall). (3) Ultrafast energy transfer between the inner- and outer-wall nanotubes. Physical understanding obtained in this project is not only of fundamental interest, but also important for nanoelectronic and nanophotonic applications based on DWNTs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merits: This DMR award aims at fundamental understanding of novel properties of 1D carbon nanotubes, with a focus on the van der Waals coupling between non-commensurate double-walled carbon nanotubes. Within this award, we have made several important contributions to understanding the light-matter interaction in one dimensional carbon nanotubes. They include (1) first observation of strong electronic coupling between the inner- and outer-walls in double-walled carbon nanotubes, and (2) first observation of the one-dimensional Luttinger liquid plasmons in carbon nanotubes.

1. First observation of strong electronic coupling between the inner- and outer-walls in double-walled carbon nanotubes:

Non-commensurate two-dimensional materials such as a twisted graphene bilayer or graphene on boron nitride, consisting of components that have no finite common unit cell, exhibit emerging moiré physics such as novel Van Hove singularities, Fermi velocity renormalization, mini Dirac points and Hofstadter butterflies. Here we use double-walled carbon nanotubes as a model system for probing moiré physics in incommensurate one-dimensional systems since each DWNT, which constitutes two tubes (inner and outer tube) is precisely defined at the atomic level with hundreds of different DWNT varieties.

We investigated the electronic coupling in 1D DWNTs experimentally through absorption spectroscopy on individual chirality-defined DWNTs. We used electron beam diffraction to uniquely determine the detailed wall structures of a DWNT, and obtained the optical transition energies of the same DWNT by optical absorption spectroscopy. By comparing the optical transition energies in DWNTs with those in isolated constituent SWNTs, we obtained quantitative information on transition energy shifts due to the electronic coupling and their dependence on the DWNT chirality. We systematically examined total 99 optical transitions from chirality-defined DWNTs. Contrary to previous theoretical predictions, which suggested a negligible inter-tube electronic coupling, electronic coupling from van der Waals interactions can be surprisingly strong in incommensurate DWNTs. The coupled electronic states can lead to either a blueshift or redshift of the optical transition energy by up to 150 meV, with the exact energy shift depending sensitively on the DWNT chirality. In addition, we developed a theory based on 1D zone folding of twisted-and-stretched graphene bilayers that successfully describes the coupled electronic states in incommensurate DWNT systems. This paper was published in Nature Physics in 2014.

2. First observation of Luttinger liquid plasmon in metallic carbon nanotubes.

The experimental observation of such Luttinger liquid plasmons in SWNTs has remained an outstanding challenge for over a decade, although previous electrical transport and photoemission measurements has shown the presence of Luttinger liquid behaviors in SWNTs. Using near field optical microscopy, we visualize in real space the plasmons in metallic SWNTs at room temperature and under ambient conditions. The Luttinger liquid plasmons in SWNTs simultaneously exhibit strong spatial confinement and a high-quality factor, two most important merits in plasmonics.

At the same time, we show that the Luttinger-liquid plasmons can be excited in a broad frequency range and that they propagate at a ‘semi-quantized’ velocity in individual carbon nanotubes. This velocity, unlike classical plasmon oscillations, does not depend on the free carrier density and varies only weakly with the plasmon frequency or nanotube diameter. Instead, it is mainly determined by the quantized number of conducting channels in carbon nanotubes. Our experimental observation of the Luttinger liquid plasmon and its propagation velocity agrees quantitatively with theoretical predictions. This work was published in Nature Photonics in 2015.

Broad Impact: Our research made significant impact on the research community studying carbon nanotubes. (1) The observation of inter-tube electronic coupling between non-commensurate inner and outer walls is fundamental for understanding the physical properties of double-walled and multi-walled carbon nanotubes. More generally, our study shows that van der Waals coupling can strongly modify the electronic structures of 1D as well as 2D incommensurate systems. It opens up new avenues in engineering the electronic and optical properties of van der Waals-coupled low-dimensional materials. (2) The combination of low dispersion, high quality factor and strong subwavelenth confinement in Luttinger liquid plasmons holds great potential for novel plasmonic and nanophotonic devices over a broad frequency range, including telecom wavelenths. In addition, the direct imaging of Luttinger liquid under ambient conditions opens up exciting new opportunities to explore both one dimensional Luttinger liquid physics and quantum plasmons in carbon nanotubes.
